facts.text: Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 76 of 1952 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURIDICTIN Petition No. 76 of 1952. Application under-Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of mandamus. J. Umrigar for the petitioner. N. Joshi for the respondent. 1952. May 7.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by MUKHERJEA J. on May 7, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.--This is an application under article 32 of the Constitution, presented by one Gurubachan Singh, praying for a writ, in the nature of mandamus restraining the respondents as well as their subordinates and successors from enforcing an externment order served on the petitioner under section 27 1  of the City of Bombay Police Act  1902 .

facts.text: Petitioner Gurubachan Singh is an Indian citizen residing with his father at Gogri Niwas, Vincent Road, Dadar; father has business in electrical goods in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is an Indian citizen and is said to be residing with his father at a place called Gogri Niwas, Vincent Road, Dadar, his father having a business in elec- trical goods in the city of Bombay On the 23rd July, 1951, the petitioner was served with an order purporting to have been made by the Commissioner of Police, Bombay, under section 27  1  of the City of Bombay Police Act, directing him to remove himself from Greater Bombay and go to his native place at Amritsar in East Punjab.

facts.text: On 23rd July 1951, petitioner served with externment order by Commissioner of Police, Bombay under section 27(1) of City of Bombay Police Act directing removal from Greater Bombay to Amritsar within two days by rail.

anchor.surface_text: On the 23rd July, 1951, the petitioner was served with an order purporting to have been made by the Commissioner of Police, Bombay, under section 27  1  of the City of Bombay Police Act, directing him to remove himself from Greater Bombay and go to his native place at Amritsar in East Punjab. It was mentioned in the order that the petitioner was to companyply with its directions within two days from the date it was made, and that he was to proceed to Amritsar by rail.

facts.text: On July 25, 1951, petitioner applied to Commissioner of Police for extension of time to remove from Greater Bombay; granted till July 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On July 25, 1951, the petitioner made an application to the Commissioner of Police and prayed for an extension of the time within which he was to remove himself from Greater Bombay, and on this application the Commissioner of Police gave him time till the 30th of July next.

facts.text: On 30th July 1951, petitioner wrote letter to Commissioner of Police stating he did not desire to go to Amritsar, requested to stay at Kalyan (outside Greater Bombay, within State of Bombay) with railway ticket from Dadar.

anchor.surface_text: On 30th July, 1951, the petitioner himself wrote a letter to the Commissioner of Police stating that he did number desire to go to Amritsar and prayed that he might be allowed to stay at Kalyan which is outside Greater Bombay but within the Slate of Bombay and that he might be given a Railway ticket from Dadar to that place.

facts.text: On evening of 30th July 1951, police took petitioner to Kalyan and left him there.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that acting on this letter the police took the petitioner to Kalyan on the evening of 30th July, 1951, and left him there.

facts.text: Petitioner commenced proceedings in Bombay High Court: first on original side under Letters Patent, then in Appellate Criminal Bench under Articles 226 and 228, complaining of externment order, praying for certiorari to quash it; both dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: After that, the petitioner companymenced proceedings in the Bombay High Court first in its original side under the Letters Patent and then in the Appellate Criminal Bench of the Court under articles 226 and 228 of the Constitution, companyplaining of the externment order mentioned above and praying for a writ of certiorari to have it quashed. Both these applications were dismissed

facts.text: Petitioner approached Supreme Court under Article 32 alleging infringement of fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(d) and (e) by the externment order.

anchor.surface_text: and the petitioner has number companye up to this companyrt under article 32 of the Constitution on the allegation that his fundamental rights under clauses  d  and  e  of article 19 1  of the Constitution have been infringed by the extern- ment order.

facts.text: Respondents admit that the externment order of 23-7-1951 is not in strict conformity with section 27(1) of the City of Bombay Police Act.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first point, it is number disputed on behalf of the respondents that the order of externment, as was passed by the Commissioner of Police on 23-7-1951, is number in strict companyformity with the provision of section 27 1  of the City of Bombay Police Act

facts.text: Externment order directed petitioner to remove from Greater Bombay but specified Amritsar (outside State of Bombay).

anchor.surface_text: The order directed the petitioner to remove himself out of Greater Bombay but at the same time mentioned Amritsar as the place where he was to go Section 27 1  of the City of Bombay Police Act provides as follows--

facts.text: Court finds irregularity in original order cured by petitioner's letter of 30 July 1951 requesting Kalyan, which was accepted, and police took him there.

anchor.surface_text: We need number, however, labour this aspect of the matter any further, for we are of the opinion that whatever irregu- larity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent companyduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any. As has been stated already, on the 30th July, 1951, the petitioner himself by a letter written to the Commis- sioner of Police sought his permission to stay at Kalyan which is within the State of Bombay.

facts.text: J. Umrigar appeared for petitioner, N. Joshi for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: J. Umrigar for the petitioner. N. Joshi for the respondent. 1952. May 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.--This is an application under article 32 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Kalyan is outside Greater Bombay but within the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: prayed that he might be allowed to stay at Kalyan which is outside Greater Bombay but within the Slate of Bombay

facts.text: Amritsar is in East Punjab, outside State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: go to his native place at Amritsar in East Punjab.

facts.text: Petitioner argued order void for not conforming to s.27(1).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Umrigar appearing in support of the petition has argued before us, in the first place that the order of externment is altogether void as it is number in companyformity with the provisions of section 27 1 of the City of Bombay Police Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed both applications by petitioner against externment order.

anchor.surface_text: Both these applications were dismissed and the petitioner has number companye up to this companyrt

facts.text: Commissioner of Police can make externment order up to two years duration and can permit entry earlier.

anchor.surface_text: The maximum dura- tion of the externment order made under section 27  1  of the Bombay Act is a period of two years and the Commissioner of Police can always permit the externee to enter the pro- hibited area even before the expiration of that period.

facts.text: Before passing externment order, Commissioner informs person in writing of general nature of allegations and gives opportunity to explain, appear through advocate, file statement, examine witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the procedure to be followed in such cases, section 27  4  of the Act lays down that before an order of externment is passed against any person, the Commissioner of Police or any officer authorized by him shall inform such person, in writing, of the general nature of the material allegations against him and give him a reasonable opportunity of ex- plaining these allegations.

facts.text: Petitioner's request to stay at Kalyan acceded to by Commissioner of Police.

anchor.surface_text: His request was acced- ed to and the Police actually took him to Kalyan on the evening of the 30th.
Application under-Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of mandamus.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.--This is an application under article 32 of the Constitution,
for a writ in the nature of mandamus. J. Umrigar for the petitioner. N. Joshi for the respondent. 1952. May 7.

arguments.claim: there are two kinds of externment orders contemplated by the subsection: one from Greater Bombay requiring specification of place within State and route; other from State requiring no specific place

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear from this provision that there are two kinds of externment orders companytemplated by the subsection one, where externment is directed from the Greater Bombay and the other where the externee is to remove himself from the State of Bombay. In the first class of cases the order has got to specify the place where the externee is to remove himself to and it must also indicate the route by which he has to reach that place.

arguments.claim: whatever irregularity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent conduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any

anchor.surface_text: We need number, however, labour this aspect of the matter any further, for we are of the opinion that whatever irregu- larity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent companyduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any.

arguments.claim: the restrictions that this law imposes upon the rights of free movement of a citizen come within the purview of clause (5) of article 19 of the Constitution; the restrictions are reasonable

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is whether the restrictions that this law imposes upon the rights of free movement of a citizen, companye within the purview of clause  5  of article 19 of the Constitution or in other words whether the restrictions are reasonable ?

arguments.claim: maximum duration of two years and revocability make the substantive restriction reasonable

anchor.surface_text: The maximum dura- tion of the externment order made under section 27  1  of the Bombay Act is a period of two years and the Commissioner of Police can always permit the externee to enter the pro- hibited area even before the expiration of that period.

arguments.claim: procedure under section 27(4) reasonable as it provides written notice, opportunity to explain, appear by advocate, file statement, examine witnesses

anchor.surface_text: As regards the procedure to be followed in such cases, section 27  4  of the Act lays down that before an order of externment is passed against any person, the Commissioner of Police or any officer authorized by him shall inform such person, in writing, of the general nature of the material allegations against him and give him a reasonable opportunity of ex- plaining these allegations.

arguments.claim: lack of right to cross-examine witnesses does not make procedure unreasonable given preventive purpose and witness safety concerns

anchor.surface_text: The only point which Mr. Umrigar attempts to make in regard to the reasonableness of this procedure is that the suspected person is number allowed to cross-examine the witnesses who deposed against him and on whose evidence the proceedings were started. In our opinion this by itself would number make the procedure unreasonable having regard to the avowed intention of the legislature in making the enact- ment.

holdings.text: whatever irregularity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent conduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any... there is really any substance in the first point raised by Mr. Umrigar

anchor.surface_text: We need number, however, labour this aspect of the matter any further, for we are of the opinion that whatever irregu- larity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent companyduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any. As has been stated already, on the 30th July, 1951, the petitioner himself by a letter written to the Commis- sioner of Police sought his permission to stay at Kalyan which is within the State of Bombay. His request was acced- ed to and the Police actually took him to Kalyan on the evening of the 30th. We think that, in these circumstances, the order made on the 23rd July, 1951, might be companystrued to be an order of externment from Greater Bombay and though there was a mistake regarding the place where the externee was to remove himself to, the mistake was rectified by the petitioner choosing Kalyan as the place of residence and that choice being accepted and given effect to by the Police Department. We do number think that in these circumstances there is really any substance in the first point raised by Mr. Umrigar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original order irregular in specifying Amritsar (outside State) for Greater Bombay externment, but cured by petitioner's letter requesting Kalyan (within State), accepted and enforced by police, rectifying defect

holdings.text: section 27(1) of the City of Bombay Police Act has imposed restrictions upon the fundamental right of a citizen which is guaranteed under article 19(1)(d) ... it is difficult to say that this provision is unreasonable

anchor.surface_text: The second point urged by the learned companynsel raises the question as to whether section 27  1  of the City of Bombay Police Act has imposed restrictions upon the funda- mental right of a citizen which is guaranteed under article 19  1   d  of the Constitution and being in companyflict with this fundamental right is void and inoperative under article 18  1  of the Constitution. There can be numberdoubt that the provision of section 27  1  of the Bombay Act was made in the interest of the general public and to protect them against dangerous and bad characters whose presence in a particular locality may jeopardize the peace and safety of the citizens. The question, therefore, is whether the restrictions that this law imposes upon the rights of free movement of a citizen, companye within the purview of clause  5  of article 19 of the Constitution or in other words whether the restrictions are reasonable ? It is perfectly true that the determination of the question as to whether the restric- tions imposed by a legislative enactment upon the fundamen- tal rights of a citizen enunciated in article 19  1  d  of the Constitution are reasonable or number within the meaning of clause  5  of the article would depend as much upon the procedural part of the law as upon its substantive part and the companyrt has got to look in each case to the circumstances under which and the manner in which the restrictions have been imposed. The maximum dura- tion of the externment order made under section 27  1  of the Bombay Act is a period of two years and the Commissioner of Police can always permit the externee to enter the pro- hibited area even before the expiration of that period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions under s.27(1) reasonable due to limited duration (max 2 years, revocable), preventive purpose against bad characters menacing public safety, in interests of general public under Art.19(5)

holdings.text: this by itself would not make the procedure unreasonable having regard to the avowed intention of the legislature in making the enactment

anchor.surface_text: As regards the procedure to be followed in such cases, section 27  4  of the Act lays down that before an order of externment is passed against any person, the Commissioner of Police or any officer authorized by him shall inform such person, in writing, of the general nature of the material allegations against him and give him a reasonable opportunity of ex- plaining these allegations. He is permitted to appear through an Advocate, or an Attorney and can file a written statement and examine witnesses for the purpose of clearing his character. The only point which Mr. Umrigar attempts to make in regard to the reasonableness of this procedure is that the suspected person is number allowed to cross-examine the witnesses who deposed against him and on whose evidence the proceedings were started. In our opinion this by itself would number make the procedure unreasonable having regard to the avowed intention of the legislature in making the enact- ment. The law is certainly an extraordinary one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where numberwitnesses for fear of violence to their person or property are willing to depose publicly against certain bad charac- ters whose presence in certain areas companystitutes a menace to the safety of the public residing therein. This object would be wholly defeated if a right to companyfront or cross- examine these witnesses was given to the suspect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.27(4) provides notice of allegations, opportunity to explain, counsel, statement, examine witnesses; no cross-exam justified as preventive measure where witnesses fear reprisal, vesting power in responsible officer ensures caution

holdings.text: the provision of section 27(1) mentioned above is discriminatory in its character and offends against article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The last companyten- tion urged, though somewhat faintly, is. that the provision of section 27 1  mentioned above is discriminatory in its character and offends against article 14 of the Constitu- tion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contention faintly urged and implicitly rejected by upholding provision and dismissing petition without substantive engagement

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that in these circumstances there is really any substance in the first point raised by Mr. Umrigar.

outcome.relief_summary: Petitioner's claims rejected; externment order construed as valid after rectification; section 27(1) held reasonable restriction under Article 19(5)

anchor.surface_text: We need number, however, labour this aspect of the matter any further, for we are of the opinion that whatever irregu- larity there might have been in the original order, the subsequent companyduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any. As has been stated already, on the 30th July, 1951, the petitioner himself by a letter written to the Commis- sioner of Police sought his permission to stay at Kalyan which is within the State of Bombay. His request was acced- ed to and the Police actually took him to Kalyan on the evening of the 30th. We think that, in these circumstances, the order made on the 23rd July, 1951, might be companystrued to be an order of externment from Greater Bombay and though there was a mistake regarding the place where the externee was to remove himself to, the mistake was rectified by the petitioner choosing Kalyan as the place of residence and that choice being accepted and given effect to by the Police Department. We do number think that in these circumstances there is really any substance in the first point raised by Mr. Umrigar.
We do not think that in these circumstances there is really any substance in the first point raised by Mr. Umrigar.

anchor.surface_text: The second point urged by the learned companynsel raises the question as to whether section 27  1  of the City of Bombay Police Act has imposed restrictions upon the funda- mental right of a citizen which is guaranteed under article 19  1   d  of the Constitution and being in companyflict with this fundamental right is void and inoperative under article 18  1  of the Constitution. There can be numberdoubt that the provision of section 27  1  of the Bombay Act was made in the interest of the general public and to protect them against dangerous and bad characters whose presence in a particular locality may jeopardize the peace and safety of the citizens. The question, therefore, is whether the restrictions that this law imposes upon the rights of free movement of a citizen, companye within the purview of clause  5  of article 19 of the Constitution or in other words whether the restrictions are reasonable ? It is perfectly true that the determination of the question as to whether the restric- tions imposed by a legislative enactment upon the fundamen- tal rights of a citizen enunciated in article 19  1  d  of the Constitution are reasonable or number within the meaning of clause  5  of the article would depend as much upon the procedural part of the law as upon its substantive part and the companyrt has got to look in each case to the circumstances under which and the manner in which the restrictions have been imposed. The maximum dura- tion of the externment order made under section 27  1  of the Bombay Act is a period of two years and the Commissioner of Police can always permit the externee to enter the pro- hibited area even before the expiration of that period.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the procedure to be followed in such cases, section 27  4  of the Act lays down that before an order of externment is passed against any person, the Commissioner of Police or any officer authorized by him shall inform such person, in writing, of the general nature of the material allegations against him and give him a reasonable opportunity of ex- plaining these allegations. He is permitted to appear through an Advocate, or an Attorney and can file a written statement and examine witnesses for the purpose of clearing his character. The only point which Mr. Umrigar attempts to make in regard to the reasonableness of this procedure is that the suspected person is number allowed to cross-examine the witnesses who deposed against him and on whose evidence the proceedings were started. In our opinion this by itself would number make the procedure unreasonable having regard to the avowed intention of the legislature in making the enact- ment. The law is certainly an extraordinary one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where numberwitnesses for fear of violence to their person or property are willing to depose publicly against certain bad charac- ters whose presence in certain areas companystitutes a menace to the safety of the public residing therein. This object would be wholly defeated if a right to companyfront or cross- examine these witnesses was given to the suspect.
